title: Father explains why he loves life with five kids in condo
text:
A single father-of-five has told how he improved his family's quality of life and happiness by condensing their lives into a 1,000 square-foot apartment.
Adrian Crook, 41, said he has always been a minimalist but after splitting up with his ex-wife he decided to take his passion to the next level by downsizing to make his lifestyle more sustainable.
Rather than opting for a house in the Vancouver, Canada , suburbs the video game design consultant decided to get a two-bedroom downtown condo.
Scroll down for video
Minimal: A single father has revealed how he improved his family's life and happiness by downsizing to a 1,000 square-foot apartment in Vancouver, Canada, pictured
Life change: Adrian Crook, 41, has always been a minimalist but after splitting up with his ex-wife he decided to take his passion to the next level
Simple: The computer game design consultant, whose five children are pictured, moved into a downtown two-bedroom condo
Video courtesy of Steve Saretsky:
'Really I've been a minimalist all my life so this type of paired down living comes naturally,' he told Daily Mail Online.
'Keeping life simple, not having a car is part of that. Being close to everything we want to access. Making life more streamlined so we can spend more time on the things that matter.'
As a result of the move, he no longer needs a car and he has easy access to the city's amenities.
His three sons and two daughters, aged between five and ten, live with him two weeks on and two weeks off.
Innovative: He customized furniture - such as triple bunk-beds and beds that turn into desks - to make best use of the space
Beliefs: He said his living decisions are based on 'cultural or moral' principals
Cost-effective: But living in a smaller space has also saved him money
When Adrian and his wife were still together the family lived in Playa del Carmen, Mexico, for three years before splitting up and relocating to Vancouver.
It took him 12 to 18 months to furnish the apartment 'from the ground up'. When he moved in he said he 'literally started without forks and knives'.
Catering for five children has led to some innovative design creations - including a triple bunk bed for the three boys made by a carpenter friend of Adrian's.
Some furniture has multiple uses - such as a lower bunk that doubles up as a table.
'There's a lot of different uses for each room and that's what keeps people out of each other's hair,' he said.
Money saving: His energy bills come to $40 a month - a huge reduction on the hundreds he used to spend living in a house
Room for all: The boys sleep in one bedroom, the girls in the other and Adrian sleeps in the 'den'
The boys sleep in one bedroom, Adrian in the other and the girls sleep in the 'den'.
When they are not with their father they live with their mother in a townhouse in the city's suburbs.
'It's hard to say what they prefer...I think they genuinely like it [the apartment]. They take the bus to and from school on their own.
'That level of freedom is something they appreciate. Living downtown they can walk to things that they can't walk to in the suburbs - the park, a coffee shop.'
Two homes: When they are not with their father the children live with their mother in a townhouse in the city's suburbs
Friendly company: When the children are at their mother's, Adrian often invites people to stay because he said it can get lonely when they are away
He said he does not believe in the 'north American' expectation that a family should have a house and at least one car.
When the children are at their mother's, Adrian often invites people to stay because he said it can get lonely when they are away. Recently he invited a friend to stay with and teach him Spanish.
Although Adrian, who writes about his experiences on his website Five Kids One Condo said his living decisions are based on 'cultural or moral' principals, they have also saved him money.
His energy bills come to $40 a month - a huge reduction on the hundreds he used to spend living in a house.
He said: 'A lot of people think living further out is cheaper...but when you add what you spend on cars it's far more expensive.'
